original_title: Sri Lankan renegotiates leases to save US$160mn
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – SriLankan Airlines has renegotiated aircraft leases saving 160 million US dollars through the remaining life of the contracts, the airline said.

“To minimise the loss resulting from the reduced air traffic revenue compared to pre COVID-19 levels, SLA has taken steps to restructure the lease agreements through extensive negotiations with lessors,” SriLankan told shareholders in the annual report.

“Hence, the resultant saving for the financial year 2021/22 was LKR 5,841 Mn (USD 28.4 Mn), whilst a total reduction of USD 160 Mn in lease rentals was received from aircraft lessors for the total remaining period of the respective lease agreements.”

The airline had also renegotiated third-party contracts pertaining to IT, product development, properties and logistics, flight operations and revenue management areas, saving 2,715 million dollars (USD 13.2 Mn) in the year to March 2022.

Sri Lankan had also negotiated with aircraft lessors to defer payments worth 23.4 million US dollar to improve cashflows.
SLA obtained interest moratoriums on the loans from state banks amounting to USD 5.26 Mn and LKR 460 Mn with a repayment period ranging from six to twelve months.
SriLankan made loss in 2022 mostly due to currency depreciation on old loans and finance costs. (Colombo/May17/2023)
